title: Got caught up in all the hype...
text: We have enjoyed their wines for some years, so a visit to the Ferrari-Carano Winery was meaningful. Unfortunately, we got caught up in all the hype (as the Caranos would hope) and bought way too many bottles. However, our traveling companions were already club members, so our treatment was top shelf, and they charged our wines to get the substantial discounted prices. The grounds really were spectacular.

title: If you like beer and noise...
text: After a wonderful day of touring a number of wineries, the Russian River Brewing Company would not have been our first as a dinner venue. However, never having been to Santa Rosa before, we relied upon our traveling companions who frequent the area often. If you like beer and noise, then this could be your cup of tea. We enjoy neither beer nor noise, but we give this restaurant a decent rating because it clearly was popular and the food was tasty. Ambience leaves something to be desired since big is not necessarily better, and elbow-to-elbow crowds do not work for us. We did not have a reservation, so got one of the worst tables next to the hostess podium.

title: Historic half of hotel has character...
text: The Hotel La Rose was perfectly located for our several days of touring the nearby wineries. They had a private parking area a block away, and a number of restaurants were within easy walking distance. The historic half of the hotel (which is where we stayed) had character, while the carriage house across the street was newer construction. We reserved early to get a better choice of rooms. Their breakfast was nothing special but adequate. All in all, it was a comfortable, clean, secure and very nice accommodation.

title: Consistently very good...
text: We have eaten at Jing Jing several times over the years. My aunt has been a fixture in Palo Alto for close to 60 years and considers this Chinese restaurant one of her favorites. We most always have their Sizzling Rice Soup and Walnut Prawns and then add other dishes as our palates desire. All their food is consistently very good.

title: Definitely not first flight...
text: After a full day of travel, upon our return to Merida, we decided to try a different restaurant for dinner. La Casta Divina was the choice. Its location in Centro was certainly convenient, the food was ok and we did not experience any post-meal problems. However, it was definitely not first flight, and there are much better options in Merida. We will probably not return.

title: A worthwhile interaction...
text: Not my dream attraction but definitely a worthwhile interaction with America's history. Unfortunately, I had not allowed adequate time to properly explore and absorb all the venue had to offer. So one day I hope to be able to return.
place: The George W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum

title: Basically a western-themed warehouse...
text: One would correctly suspect that we were at Eddie Deen's Ranch while attending a convention. This venue easily accommodated our 1000+ attendees but was basically a western-themed warehouse. The mass-produced buffet was palatable and filling, but the bars (despite the fact that they were no host) were definitely a necessity.

title: A sense of walking into history...
text: No matter one's political orientation, it would be a crime to visit Dallas and not explore The Sixth Floor Museum at Dealey Plaza. From the moment we stepped off the elevator, there was a sense of walking into history. The exhibits are well done and definitely thought provoking.
place: Sixth Floor Museum at Dealey Plaza Admission

title: A legitimate BBQ joint...
text: Whatever we have ordered at Wood Shop BBQ has always been very good. Whether it is their chicken, brisket, pulled pork or ribs, they never disappoint. Adding their kale salad really helps us to imagine we are having a healthy meal! For digestive reasons, I really should not gobble down any of their Mac & Cheese dishes but always seem to do so anyway...special treat! Because there previously has always been a huge line for ordering and we really need to social distance now because of our ages, we would prefer that Wood Shop BBQ had a delivery option. Regardless, they truly are a legitimate BBQ joint.

title: Dramatic local area attraction...
text: On a clear day, the 30-minute drive toward the mountains east of Seattle is a wonderful respite. The payoff is the dramatic local area attraction named Snoqualmie Falls. Unlike similar water features in other parts of the country and world, this waterfall is easily viewed and accessible. Numerous platforms are positioned for some fantastic photo ops. Bring some comfortable shoes if you'll want to do some additional walking and/or trail hiking. There is no admission charge, and free parking is also available.

title: Unparalleled brunch...
text: A clear, sunny Pacific Northwest day is optimum, but even poor weather will not dampen the unparalleled brunch experience at The Dining Room at Salish Lodge. It is always a great spot for entertaining out-of-town visitors, plus there is the added benefit of treating ourselves to a wonderful brunch. Everything on the breakfast menu is fantastic but our favorites are definitely the Dungeness Crab Benedict and Dungeness Crab Omelet. Throw in their fresh honey on savory biscuits and a Bloody Mary or two and voilà! We always make reservations well in advance for best seating.
place: The Dining Room at Salish Lodge & Spa

title: If only there were more Gluten Free options for delivery...
text: Normal times would probably find us abroad and at the least enjoying dinners out multiple times each week when not traveling. However, these days are nothing close to anything we would consider normal. The Metropolitan Grill provides us with a very good, reasonable option for continuing to enjoy fine food delivered to our home. No need to unnecessarily be exposed to any germs. Just pop the ready-to-heat/bake food in the oven. On several occasions, I have enjoyed the King Salmon entree and Grilled Asparagus side. Sadly, I could only imagine how wonderful the Crab Cakes and Crab Crusted Halibut were tasting. If only there were more Gluten Free options for delivery from the Metropolitan Grill, then it could definitely be a weekly go-to dinner delivery option.

title: Gluten free pizza delivered...
text: Due to the current virus issues, we have chosen to have some of our dinners delivered. We have ordered a number of times from Pagliacci Pizza and have been quite satisfied. Both online or by phone has been easy, and food arrives within 30-45 minutes. Their seasonal special is chicken sausage and mushrooms which we have enjoyed on both regular and gluten free pizza. Most importantly, we do not have to leave the house since our pizzas, salads, etc. are delivered. No public contact at all.

title: An extraordinary gastronomic experience...
text: Restaurant Fangst was located in the basement of our hotel - The Saga Hotel Oslo. Although the menu offered a nice variety of à la carte options, it had been recommended that we choose omakase - a meal where the customer leaves it up to the chef to select five or eight dishes. We opted for the five dishes, plus wine pairings which ended up being totally perfect. The culinary skills of Chef Håkan Wiik were on full display. For an incredible evening of fine dining in a relaxed, casual environment and an extraordinary gastronomic experience, Restaurant Fangst was truly wonderful. And not surprisingly, the service was impeccable. In our opinion, this restaurant would be the perfect find for any epicure.

title: An Italian food jackpot...
text: Dal Baffo Ristorante Bar Italiano was truly a relatively undiscovered gem in Merida. It can proudly take credit for being amongst the very best Italian restaurants in the area. Their pasta was all homemade and freshly prepared on a daily basis. We had the pleasure of dining there several times previously and always tried different dishes...tagliatelle with various ingredients and sauces, caprese salad, eggplant parmigiana to name a few. Adding a nice bottle of Barbera wine, panna cotta dessert or some limoncello just rounded out the dining experience. We found Dal Baffo Ristorante Bar Italiano to be an Italian food jackpot. Excellent fare, personable service, very reasonable prices and all had in a casual, unpretentious setting.

title: Marvelous breakfast buffet...
text: Everything about the Hilton Da Nang was top shelf. The spacious suite, commanding view and Executive Lounge were wonderful. We looked forward to the marvelous breakfast buffet each day, with its freshly-prepared dishes and huge variety of choices. From its tremendously helpful and friendly staff to the hotel's convenient location, the Hilton Da Nang was a perfect choice.

title: Surprisingly ornate interior...
text: It is always interesting to visit the primary religious attraction of any city in the world, and Basilica Cattedrale di Foggia was no exception. The interior decor was surprisingly ornate compared to the building's exterior. Various altars and icons were striking and quite beautiful. It was a worthwhile stop.

title: Nice little plaza...
text: Piazza Umberto Giordano was a nice little plaza which provided a place to rest. There are some interesting sculptures to view, including one of Umberto Giordano, but not much else.

title: Scenic location overlooking Piazza Umberto Giordano...
text: Chiesa Gesù e Maria is undoubtedly frequently photographed due to its scenic location overlooking the Piazza Umberto Giordano. While the baroque-styled building is not particularly striking, its simple lines and decorations are actually refreshing. The interior of the church is quite nice, with beautiful dome fresco and an uncluttered feel. It was worth the visit.

title: A beautifully landscaped welcoming space...
text: The stunning entrance to Parco Urbano Karol Wojtyla is a magnificent, columned portico. The colonnaded entry is preceded by the Fontana del Sele in the Piazza Cavour. Inaugurated in 1924, the fountain is the oldest in the city and became the symbol of Foggia. Parco Urbano Karol Wojtyla, named after Pope John Paul II, provided a great change of pace from the bustling streets of Foggia. This beautifully landscaped and well-maintained park, with its promenade and multiple water features, was a wonderful large open welcoming space in the middle of the city. However, with the exception of a number of dog walkers, there were surprisingly few others enjoying the place. Perhaps because it was just Noon, more people would frequent later in the day.

title: Opened up restaurant early just for me...
text: Apparently in Foggia, many restaurants normally open at 12 Noon or later, and those which served a breakfast seemed to close early. So finding one which was both open and served any food at 11am had been virtually impossible. My train departing Foggia for Lecce was at 1:22pm. Having not eaten much breakfast, I had been walking around the streets with my luggage for several hours looking for an open restaurant before coming upon Nikita. They were clearly still closed but I stopped to inquire if they could suggest someplace which was open for lunch. I explained my situation and the waiter walked me back to a dining area and opened up early just for me. Although I honestly cannot now recall what they prepared for me, I do know that the food and drink was great. As the waiter prepped the other tables for opening and did his side work, he was both friendly and engaging. It was my final impression of Foggia and certainly made a positive one...left a "good taste" so to speak! I would return to Nikita in a heartbeat.

title: Oldest church in Salzburg...
text: Small but strikingly impressive, Michaelskirche (St. Michael's Church) dates from about 780 and is the oldest church in Salzburg. It served as both the imperial chapel and parish church until the 12th century and had different entrances to two completely separate floors. The upper floor was intended for the emperor and his entourage and the lower floor for citizens of the city. The altars are beautifully decorated with paintings of the Archangel Michael conquering Lucifer in the center and of the two archangels, Gabriel and Raphael, to either side. The ceiling fresco depicts the adoration of God by Archangel Michael by Franz Nikolaus Streicher, and the ornate screen grillwork by Philipp Hinterseer is absolutely magnificent - both from 1770.

title: Deserves a rating of less than zero...
text:
If Al Giordano B&B had followed through with their emailed promises, then the stay at their establishment would probably have been very good. However, from the onset, it was a terrible experience.

The B&B's reservation page stated that check-in ends at 17:00 daily. So, being a responsible traveler and wanting to avoid problems, I emailed them slightly over a month in advance and advised them that "my train...arrives at 17:19. Will this be a problem for check-in?" Their immediate reply was, "Good morning, No problem, dont' [sic] worry [smiley face]." When I arrived by taxi from the train station, the main door to the building was locked, and there was no response to the B&B buzzer. I waited, and buzzed, and waited, and buzzed, and finally made calls to my spouse who was also traveling but in another part of Italy to obtain the B&B's phone number. After several attempts to reach them, someone finally answered and indicated that he would come to the B&B. I continued to wait on the street door stoop until another building resident let me enter and then sat on the floor in front of the B&B's second floor door. Finally, Valerio arrived and checked me into my room at 8:10pm!!!

The room was actually very nice, clean and appeared to have been recently renovated. It had a narrow, but usable, balcony which was a good extra. However, because there was a restaurant/bar directly below, the drunken conversations and noise was annoying. I had been given verbal directions for where to go to get the second "B" of B&B. But when I arrived and explained that I had been sent from Al Giordano B&B, they advised that there would be a charge for anything except a roll and coffee...wonderful! To top it off, checkout was exactly at 10am. Even though they were three hours late in letting me into my room, there would be no extension of the checkout time, so I dragged my luggage around Foccia until my 1:22pm train to Lecce. This property deserves a rating of less than zero, but in fairness, the room was very nice, albeit expensive, and the location quite central to the city center.

title: Spartan, no-frills interior but very good food...
text: Looking for a nice restaurant for dinner, I happened upon Trattoria del Cacciatore. It was brightly lit from the outside and appeared suitably inviting. It made no difference to me that there were no other customers on a Tuesday evening after 8pm. The restaurant had a modern, spartan, no-frills interior, so not a lot of atmosphere, but was clean and served very good food. Service was understandably excellent but also extremely helpful and friendly. Including the obligatory table cover charge, the total cost of my tasty entree, side salad, liter of water and several glasses of wine was 18.50 euro...quite reasonable. After an extremely arduous day of travel from San Marino, the dining experience at Trattoria del Cacciatore was a great way to relax, enjoy and unwind.

title: Private pool for our suite...
text:
Le Chanthou Boutique Hotel was perfectly situated in a safe, quiet residential neighborhood adjacent to the bustling, high-traffic tourist area. As such, we were close enough to access Siem Reap Central and the madness of Pub Street via the hotel's courtesy tuk tuk but far enough away to avoid all the noise and hoards of people.

The hotel and grounds were constantly being cleaned and visually impressive and inviting. The staff were totally accommodating and extremely friendly. They even accepted some suggestions and constructive criticism. As an example, during one of the several times we had dinner at the hotel, we noticed that their large plants were covered with dust, as was some of the woodwork. We simply mentioned our observations to the manager, and the following day, the restaurant was immaculate. Since we regularly enjoyed white wine with our meals and during sun breaks by the pool and non-touring days, the bar staff always had a cold bottle for us in the refrigerator...very nice. Breakfast was included, with made-to-order entrees, fresh fruit, etc. and was quite tasty. It sometimes took a while because everything was freshly prepared, but we just enjoyed our teas, coffees and juices for laid-back morning dining. Although it was easy to go to the Pub Street tourist heaven for the myriad of sit-down restaurants and food carts which we opted to do several times during our stay, we also chose to eat at the hotel for some dinners. We especially enjoyed the Khmer foods like the fried rice in pineapple and red chicken curry, but as westerners we appreciated being able to get fresh, mixed green salads which were wonderful. Snacking on spring rolls by the hotel pool was also a treat.

We needed to book several rooms because our brother joined us on the trip. The Premier Suite overlooking the hotel pool was not too shabby, but for us, the King Suite with adjoining private pool was absolutely amazing. It was great to be able to enjoy a bottle of wine by our pool before bedtime and after a full day of touring. Their room rates were surprisingly reasonable for what we considered to be a first-class property.

For Siem Reap, Le Chanthou Boutique Hotel certainly deserved more than their three-star rating, and we look forward to booking there once again when we return to the area.

title: Totally out of place...
text: In such an historic city with rich artifact to be seen everywhere, the Statua Grande Nudo Femminile seemed totally out of place. OK, it is a life-sized nude female cast in bronze.
placeLocation: City of San Marino, San Marino

title: A perfect souvenir...
text: Even though the Republic of San Marino is completely surrounded by Italy, there is no tourist visa required to enter. But for only five euro, the Tourism Office will apply a colorful stamp to your passport and affix an official date. This makes a perfect souvenir.
placeLocation: City of San Marino, San Marino

title: Have your passport beautifully stamped and officially dated...
text:
The City of San Marino was one of the most unique, incredible places in the world. Yes, it did indeed rely upon tourist traffic, but in that regard, it was not unlike London, Paris, New York City, Rome and Tokyo which many of us still choose as travel destinations. From the moment of entering San Marino by bus and walking past some of the city's ramparts to my hotel, there was an overwhelming sense of being immersed in history and hearkening back to medieval times.

For those who will visit, I would offer three suggestions. First, if practical, purchase a multi-museum pass which is valid for one entry to First Tower, Second Tower, the three primary galleries/museums and the Public Palace if Parliament is not in session. This ticket is valid for ten days from date of entry to your first attraction, so it provided the most flexibility to avoid the crowds and leisurely tour at my own pace. Second, make sure to wear comfortable shoes. Not only are there distances between some attractions like the Towers, but also the city is built across/on a hillside which required walking throughout. Third, the Republic of San Marino does not require a tourist visa to enter the country. However, for five euro, you can obtain a unique souvenir of your visit to San Marino. Have your passport beautifully stamped and officially dated at the Tourist Information Office. It is a gorgeous reminder of my wonderful visit to the oldest surviving sovereign state and constitutional republic in the world.
placeLocation: City of San Marino, San Marino

title: Lots to see but lines everywhere..
text:
Fascinating glimpse into history with lots to see. If one did not have to wait in lines to visit portions of this huge attraction, then several hours could easily have been enough time to enjoy the exhibits, art, artifact and activities. That said, I just carried energy bars, skipped stopping for snacks/food and managed to be in the short lines when most of the normal masses needed to take their lunch and dinner breaks. Buy the more expensive ticket which includes entry into everything because it's less hassle and you'll want to see it all anyway. If you have the flexibility, then consider spreading out your Duomo visit over the number of days covered by your ticket.

As an aside, beneath the existing Duomo - Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore are the preserved vestiges of the old basilica of Santa Reparata. I think a lot of people skip this part of the complex, but it is included with your ticket once you've gained entry into the church and is definitely worth seeing.
place: Duomo - Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore

title: Unfortunately many tourists may bypass...
text: The Museo dell'Opera del Duomo houses a fine collection of art and artifact which over the years have been removed from the cathedral, bell tower and baptistery and allows for a more organized viewing by the public, as well as ensuring preservation and security. Unfortunately many tourists may bypass this museum (as I almost did) expecting it to simply be more of the same and of lesser significance. Happily, I invested the time to visit.

title: Absolutely not to be missed...
text: Like those of the Vatican Museums in Vatican City, Louvre in Paris, Museum of Egyptian Antiquities in Cairo, Smithsonian Museums in Washington, D.C., Hermitage in Saint Petersburg, Prado in Madrid and so many more, the amazing masterpieces in the Uffizi Gallery of Florence, Italy are absolutely not to be missed. Even the very steep admission charge of 20 Euro should not deter. Enjoy!

title: Could easily be likened to a free, outdoor museum...
text: Since its inception in the 1330's, the Piazza della Signoria has been the political heart of Florence and one of the most significant public places in Italy. The fortress-like Palazzo Vecchio fronts on the square and is the city's town hall. The Piazza also features a copy of Michelangelo's David statue, as well the gallery of statues in the adjacent Loggia dei Lanzi. It could easily be likened to a free, outdoor museum.

title: Definitely not for tourists...
text:
The sole purpose for the vacation visit to Florence was to enjoy its renown beauty and charm and to leisurely explore some of its famous attractions. Unfortunately, the Hilton Florence Metropole was not suited to complement or support this purpose. By its mere location which was well outside the city core, the hotel could not even adequately compensate with their shuttle bus. In its defense, the hotel does publicize that their shuttle drops guests at the train station in the city center. However, they conveniently mask the fact that the purported five-minute walk is a much longer one thru back roads and walkways from the bus stop to the train station...not to the city center or any of the tourist destinations. When visiting as a tourist, it is highly normal to not be on fixed time schedules and to tour at one's leisure. By requiring hotel guests to purchase/reserve a shuttle bus ticket in advance (preferably per the hotel the day before), it substantially restricted any flexibility. At least we should have been able to expect some semblance of reliability, even given the hotel's disclaimer about not accepting responsibility for delays, etc., but one evening their 7pm bus from city center back to the hotel did not even show up until after 9pm and only then after numerous complaint calls to the hotel. A number of us therefore missed accessing the Executive Lounge before it had closed, and the hotel was totally unapologetic and uncaring.

As a Hilton property, regardless for business or tourism, the Hilton Florence Metropole was really only a mediocre hotel. It was badly in need of renovation or maybe even demolition and re-building. The hotel room was spartan, water pressure in the shower was either only warm or hot and then just a trickle. The internet throughout the hotel was not particularly good but from the room it was worse - unstable and inconsistent. Overall, the hotel staff was professional and helpful. When the hotel tried to overcharge my room at a 43% higher rate, the front desk graciously corrected the problem...especially when I provided them with a printed copy of my emailed confirmation. So if one is traveling on business where your company is picking up the tab, paying for taxis or a rental car and wasting time getting to/from destinations in the city is not an issue, then this hotel might fill the bill. However, it is definitely not for tourists...even Diamond level.

title: Fun just to window shop...
text: Ponte Vecchio in Florence spans the Arno River at its narrowest point. It is said that a bridge in its location dates back to Roman times and has suffered destruction due to flooding several times. Interesting shops line both sides, so it was fun just to window shop. Its history as the oldest bridge in Florence makes it a popular tourist attraction.

title: Unforgettable monuments and artistic treasures...
text: The Basilica of Santa Croce in Florence was quite the special attraction. It was definitely not just a magnificent, enormous church but in reality a fantastic museum filled with unforgettable monuments and artistic treasures. Priceless artworks took the form of paintings, sculptures and impressive tomb markers. Strolling past the tombs and memorials of such luminaries as Galileo, Michelangelo, Marconi, Machiavelli, Florence Nightingale and Rossini was like taking a momentary awe-inspiring step into history. Do not pass on a visit to the Basilica of Santa Croce because it would be a crime of the highest order.

title: Just enjoy your stress-free visit to Lecce...
text: Lecce is a wonderful Italian city, which combines both contemporary and traditional attitudes. The older parts of Lecce provided us with the flavor of old-time Italy with its Roman attractions and centuries-old churches, while the modern city easily could boast of some fantastic eateries and provided a welcome break from the hustle, stress, attitude and posturing prevalent in the larger cities and other habitual Italian tourist destinations.

title: Reasonable and right in the train/bus station...
text: We had traveled by train from Lecce to Bari and were waiting to catch our bus from Bari Central to the Bari/Durres ferry. The C House Bakery Cafe, located right in the train/bus station, provided the perfect spot to sit down and enjoy a snack and some wine at reasonable prices. Actually, we probably ended up buying them out of their bagged chips! The staff was wonderful, friendly and having a good time. We appreciated being able to use their clean, customers-only restroom.

title: Kick back for breakfast...
text: We discovered Caffe Raphael 78 early on during our stay in Lecce. It was located just around the corner from our air b&b and was perfect for just kicking back for a leisurely breakfast. The staff were always helpful, friendly and even entertaining. The food options were ample and prices quite reasonable. We even stopped by one afternoon after touring for a fattening, sugary dessert!

title: Amazing gourmet dining experience...
text: Recommended by a waiter (in another first-class restaurant) as the best in the city, the 3 Rane Ristoro absolutely lived up to the billing. It has a minuscule footprint and burgeoning favorable reputation, so reservations would be highly suggested. We enjoyed a good bottle of wine and opted for the full sampler menu of Chef Maurizio's creations. It was a never-to-be-forgotten, amazing gourmet dining experience...3 Rane Ristoro - truly a hidden gem.

title: Ancient cemetery of Athens...
text: Both our visit to the museum in Kerameikos and strolling portions of the grounds of this ancient cemetery of Athens were extremely interesting. It was actually quite a unique experience walking the Street of Tombs with the massive graveside markers and monuments rising around you. Definitely a different feel of ancient Athens than that evoked by the Acropolis and Parthenon...but no less striking.

title: There was much to explore...
text: Situated on one of the slopes of the Acropolis, the Ancient Agora of Athens served as the primary center of all activity for the ancient city. The expansive grounds originally sported a multitude of monuments, statues, altars, temples, covered walkways (stoas), theaters and the like. Accordingly, there was much to explore, plus the museum housed in the Stoa of Attalos was most educational.

title: Scratch it off the bucket list...
text: The Acropolis and Parthenon...once in a lifetime must see, scratch it off the bucket list and never have to endure the massive, pushy crowds of Athens ever again.

title: A great time from late afternoon until...
text: After enduring a full day of pushy crowds and sweltering heat, we didn't really care where we chose to enjoy some good wine and a meal. Located on a convergence of streets, the outside dining area for Taverna Orea Pentelli seemed like a reasonable choice. To be perfectly honest, we can't really remember what we ordered, but luckily it must have been good Greek food. We took some pictures, and the receipt says it cost 59.50 EUR. We do remember, however, having a great time from late afternoon until well into the evening! The mixture of local and foreign pedestrian traffic was really quite fun and entertaining to follow.

title: Wonderful hotel at a fraction of the name brands...
text: Convenient location, safe and secure environment, professional and helpful staff, tasty breakfast offerings and comfortable rooms...a wonderful hotel at a fraction of the price of the name brands. What more can one expect, especially when they graciously provided us with upgraded accommodations? When we were initially looking to reserve lodging for our visit to Athens, we were appalled by the seemingly exorbitant hotel prices at several of our favorite international haunts. Admittedly, we were reluctant to try the Pallas Athena Grecotel Boutique Hotel, even with its very good reviews. However, we were not disappointed, would highly recommend it to other travelers and would definitely stay there again.

title: Actually quite unbelievable...
text: Regardless of one's philosophical or political leanings, an American coming upon a Statue of George W. Bush, in a quiet town halfway around the world in Albania, was actually quite unbelievable. The plaque commemorating George W. and Laura's visit, the street named after him and the bakery with his namesake (with tasty pastries to boot) were all just frosting on the cake...so to speak.

title: Lack of translation diminished the experience...
text: There was actually quite a lot to see within the Kruja Castle complex. The castle itself actually had some interesting exhibits and artwork, but the lack of translations diminished the experience. Upon entry, the huge bas-relief sculpture of Skanderbeg and the League of Lezhë military alliance of feudal lords was most striking. Wonderful weather allowed for an enjoyable afternoon of exploration.

title: They knew we were coming...
text: The solitary, cobblestone pathway leading up to Kruja Castle was lined with the wood-constructed shops of the Old Bazaar. There was a unique feel to this low-key marketplace which tended to take one back centuries with its variety of wares. However, it almost seemed like they knew we were coming (which of course they didn't) because we found a number of items perfect for the upcoming holiday gifting. We quite enjoyed our browsing and shopping experience and even found the prices to be reasonable...compared to the other tourist areas in Albania. Take as little or as much time as you want.

title: Perfect for both dining and people watching...
text: Our day trip to the Adriatic coastal city of Durres included a leisurely stroll along its Promenade, which was replete with wonderful sculptures, interesting hotel designs and easy access to attractions such as the Durres Archaeological Museum. We found the outside seating area at Restorant Rimini to be perfect for both dining and people watching. Together with glasses of white wine, our salads and Italian dishes were very good. The only drawback worth noting was the presence of persistent young beggars who circulated amongst the tables and were quite annoying.

title: A surviving Venetian tower fortification...
text: A very small part of the history of Durres is preserved in the form of a surviving Venetian tower fortification. It has been converted to a bar called La Torra, which provided a nice view from the top while enjoying our glasses of wine. Be warned that one must navigate an original stone stairway to reach the rooftop seating area.

title: Impressive for its location, size and age...
text: We found a few attractions of interest in Durres, like the Grand Mosque, Archaeological Musuem, Promenade and Venetian Castle. But particularly impressive for its location, size and age was the Durres Amphitheatre. Having visited amphitheatres and colisuem around the world including that of Rome, we appreciated that what we were touring in Durres was on a different scale. However, the importance which Rome must have attached to Durres and the port was evident from the size of this arena. It dates from the early 2nd century A.D. and is purportedly the largest in the Balkans with a capacity of about a third of Rome's Colosseum. It was fun to be able to explore on our own, wandering the cells and tunnels beneath the stands and taking in some of the surprising surviving mosaics. Apparently, Albania continues to consider further excavation and restoration which would be fantastic.

title: The Main Plaza for Tirana...
text: Similar to Town Squares in the USA or Zócalos in Mexico, Skanderbeg Square serves as the Main Plaza for Tirana. Numerous local attractions can be quickly accessed, viewed and photographed from this city center focal point. It also served as a peaceful resting area for necessary touring breaks.

title: A testament to quality 18th-century construction...
text: As a testament to the quality of construction before the onset of modern times, Tanners' Bridge is a stone footbridge of the 18th-century Ottoman period. It is still in use today as a pedestrian only walkway.

title: Experience true local flair...
text: Not your expected tourist hangout, but clearly visitors are drawn to Apfelwein Wagner. In our case, though, a local friend took us there to experience true local flair...from the clientele, to the decor, to the food, to the drink. Bratwurst, Grilled Knuckle of Pork, all the fixings and appropriately washed down with both regular wine and traditional apfelwein made for a great meal...and a wonderful time.

title: Good option for meal delivery to hotel...
text: Since our hotel's restaurant was not open due to COVID-19 impact, they provided nearby options for food delivery. One of the menus was for cuban cuisine from Casa Juan Restaurant. Our meal consisted of 1/2 Baked Chicken, Roasted Pork with Tamal and Yuca, a small House Salad and most importantly a bottle of chardonnay. It was actually quite good but way too much food. They added a delivery charge of $2.50 and brought a portable credit card machine with them. It was great not to have to be exposed to the general public and a good option for meal delivery to the hotel.

title: Sunset on Hong Kong...
text: The day trip to Lantau Island was totally a last-minute decision. Our flight from Hong Kong to San Francisco had been delayed from 12 Noon until 10:30PM, so we literally had an entire extra day. Taking the opportunity to do some new exploring seemed appropriate. Our Crystal cabin cable car with glass floor was quite the experience. Although Ngong Ping Village was basically just a theme park and tourist trap, visits to the nearby Big Buddha attraction and Po Lin Monastery complex made for a full, interesting afternoon...and then it was sunset on Hong Kong.
place: Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car Ticket on Lantau Island

title: Fishing village was a highlight...
text: Our visit to a remote fishing village was a highlight, since most of the locals were actually just normal locals. What a unique concept! There was a lot of beautiful scenery to be had, and the leisurely touring was actually quite a nice change.
place: Hue to Hoi An or Hoi An to Hue sightseeing Son Tra Peninsula and Fishing Village

title: Just a gimmick but still fun...
text: The Dragon Bridge was built between 2009 and 2013 across the Han River. It really is just a gimmick but still fun. In Chinese culture, since the dragon is a symbol of power, strength and good luck, we of course had to visit and take a picture.

title: Exquisite sandstone sculptures...
text: Museums abound in every corner of the world. However, those housing items unique to specific cultures, faiths, regions, etc. often carry a different significance. The Da Nang Museum of Cham Sculpture is one such interesting showroom. The collection of sculptures is the largest of its kind in the world and purportedly dates back to the 7th century. Amongst its impressive Cham artifact are exquisite sandstone sculptures.
place: Da Nang Museum of Cham Sculpture

title: The stays were superb...
text:
We selected the Hilton Garden Inn Hong Kong Mongkok for its good location and proximity to public transportation and local attractions and were not disappointed. The hotel was well-maintained and basically felt secure.

To a person, the Front Desk staff were excellent. On a daily basis, before we left the hotel, they would provide advice as to expected large local gatherings and areas we should avoid within the city. Our experience with the hotel's restaurant, however, was not stellar, but the breakfast buffet was excellent. A nice blending of East and West tastes provided a great variety of foods, and made-to-order items were also available. They even brought out gluten free breads for us upon request. We have reviewed the Eagle's Garden Restaurant separately.

We understand that the hotel's owner loves the player piano music from the bar area, which was actually quite nice. However, the volume should be lowered so as not to negatively impact conversations taking place at the Front Desk. At times, one needed to almost yell to be heard. Also, because the hotel is cornered on well-trafficked streets, we observed a number of locals enter the hotel, seat themselves in the lobby and/or bar areas, and proceed to enjoy various food items from their shopping bags, purses, etc. in the presence of hotel guests trying to themselves enjoy snacks and drinks. There should probably be better control over the wandering locals. All in all, the several times we were at the Hilton Garden Inn Hong Kong Mongkok during our recent trip, the stays were superb. Although it is now highly unlikely that we will ever return to Hong Kong, we wish the hotel good fortune and especially the staff Godspeed in these challenging times both in your region and worldwide.
place: Hilton Garden Inn Hong Kong Mongkok

title: Very tasty Cantonese food but a cafeteria ambience...
text: During our several stays at the hotel, we opted to dine in for evening meals. The chef must have been very good because our Cantonese dishes were always quite tasty. Service, however, was another matter entirely. The only excellent service was provided by Eric Yuen. The other servers, including a sourpuss who we believe was a manager, should just have stayed home. As for atmosphere, the ambience of a cafeteria would be better. From the glaring bright lights turned all the way up to the blaring, piped-in player-piano music from the downstairs bar/lobby, the restaurant was actually unpleasant. If the hotel management actually cares about attracting clientele who enjoy fine Cantonese dining, and especially at the somewhat elevated prices, they should make some subtle changes for their dinner service. Perhaps providing different uniforms for the wait staff, other than the same ones worn to serve the morning breakfast buffet, might also be classier. The 20% discount on food (not including alcohol) for hotel guests was a nice touch, but then they add 10% back on the non-discounted total. One evening we just ordered off the restaurant menu but ate in the bar, with Eric serving, to avoid the so-called restaurant.

title: Probably a very good Hilton property during normal times...
text: After more than several months, we were finally able to book a domestic flight back to the US from Mexico. The airline connections were spotty and forced us to overnight in Miami. Fortunately, the Hilton Miami Airport Blue Lagoon had just re-opened several days earlier, but it was clear that they needed to do a lot of fine tuning. Upon arrival at the airport, we called the hotel and listened to the recorded instructions regarding their shuttle which would be running continuously every 30 or so minutes. However, after waiting in excess of 50 minutes, we spoke directly with a hotel employee who indicated that she would advise the shuttle driver and that we should look for a car...not a van or bus. When the bus...not a car...arrived, the driver told us that we had needed to CALL the hotel to arrange for airport pick-up. We might still have been waiting! The hotel had signs posted throughout which advised that face coverings were required in the hotel public areas. It is one thing to post signs and yet another to actually enforce compliance. Although the hotel employees all had face coverings, most of the people which we presume were guests did not! Social distancing in the lobby was not even enforced. We are senior citizens and had not been out in public for almost three months before this trip to try to get home and were very disturbed by the lack of attention to enforcement of safety precautions. We appreciated the upgrade to a very nice suite since we literally spent our entire time in the room. Since their restaurant was closed and there was no room service, we ordered food delivered as well as some wine. The hotel front desk was kind enough to provide a list of nearby restaurants. Prices in the hotel's "grab and go" store were more than astronomical, but breakfast in the morning was quite reasonable since it was covered by our status. The few employees which were visible were all quite friendly and helpful, and the hotel appeared very clean and ready to accept guests again. We suspect that the Hilton Miami Airport Blue Lagoon is probably a very good Hilton property during normal times. Unfortunately, the timing of our stay was definitely not normal.

title: A refreshing change of pace...
text: A visit to Hong Kong could not be complete without a ride on the famous Star Ferry. It has apparently run continuously between Hong Kong Island and Kowloon since 1888 and even today still serves as a vital transportation link. The short ride across Victoria Harbour was relaxing, enjoyable and reasonable. It also gave us an opportunity to view Hong Kong from a different perspective...not from a high rise or the top of a hill. Quite a refreshing change of pace.

title: A mini-Forbidden City but still impressive...
text: Even after a full morning of touring, a visit to the Hue Imperial City (The Citadel) was on our agenda. We likened it to a mini-Forbidden City but still impressive. Certain aspects of the Hue Imperial City were actually more interesting...perhaps because it felt more "lived in" and was on a smaller scale. It particular, we thoroughly enjoyed the Royal Theater, and the grounds were very well maintained. Glad we made the extra effort to visit.

title: Clearly a regular "tour" stop and a pleasant surprise...
text: Lunch was included in our Hue City Tour package, so the choice of Y Thao Garden Restaurant was not ours. The restaurant definitely had a wonderful "garden" atmosphere, and from the onset, the service was impeccable. When they presented us with a pre-printed fixed menu, it was clear that Y Thao Garden was a regular "tour" stop. We ordered glasses of white white and proceeded to enjoy our spring rolls, vegetable soup, Hue specialty pancake, mixed fig salad, fried fish with lemongrass, mixed steamed lotus rice and a dessert of fruit and green bean cake. Our first dish, the spring rolls, was served on a peacock formed from a pineapple and carrot carvings...amazing artistry and a fantastic presentation. Frankly, the food was excellent and a pleasant surprise for a set menu. Given the opportunity, we would surely return but unfortunately are unlikely to be able to do so.

title: Most ornate of Nguyen Dynasty royal tombs...
text: The Tomb of Khai Dinh, most ornate of Nguyen Dynasty royal tombs, was magnificently decorated using pieces of glass, porcelain and ceramic mosaics in a rainbow of bright colors. In places, the decor might even be likened to a kaleidoscope. Khai Dinh was purportedly gay, and a life-sized bronze statue of him sitting on a throne adorns his crypt. The incredible detail and ornateness of the inlaid mosaics are a testament to the skills of the Vietnamese artisans who worked on the tomb. We took our time climbing the steep stairs which front the tomb complex and stopped at various levels along the way to enjoy the surrounds. Viewing the interior of Thien Dinh Palace, which houses the crypt, was well worth the effort.

title: Simply an amusement park...
text: The total experience was actually terrible, but because it was partly our fault for not checking into the "attraction" in more detail before going all the way out there from Da Nang, we are being fair and rating it "Average." Basically, Ba Na Hills was simply an amusement park...and not a great one at that. Our bad, but we were expecting a stunning, natural attraction. We paid the $30+ USD per person entry fee and made the best of a bad situation. At least we got lots of steps walking through some of the gardens and even paid for over-priced wine in their "ancient" wine cellar. What a disappointment and wasted afternoon.

title: Lady Buddha statue tallest in Vietnam...
text: Located on the outskirts of Da Nang city, the Linh Ung Pagoda features the Lady Buddha statue - the tallest Buddha statue in Vietnam. The pagoda compound is extensive, beautifully landscaped and very serene. Unfortunately, its growing popularity amongst tourists could also have the negative impact of overcrowding the site.

title: Creative use of historic buildings...
text: In the midst of the Central Business District, the Tai Kwun Centre for Heritage & Arts demonstrates the creative use of historic buildings as a dramatic backdrop for an important cultural center in Hong Kong. The approximate 45-minute walking tour of the former Central Police Station, Magistrate's House and Victoria Prison was definitely worthwhile, conducted in English and without cost. It helped us to better understand the detailed and interesting history of the compound. For a nice break from touring and shopping, grab a lawn chair in the Parade Ground and just do some people watching.

title: World's longest outdoor covered escalator system...
text: Hong Kong's Central-Mid-levels Escalator is the world's longest outdoor covered escalator system. It consists of one-way escalators and moving walkways...downhill in the morning and uphill from mid-morning through the evening. We rode it uphill from the bottom to the top and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. However, rather than walk the stairs back down the hill, we actually called an Uber! The system obviously serves as a great means of local transportation but for us was also a very interesting Hong Kong attraction.

title: Just to say you had done it...
text: As expected, the views were magnificent and the tram ride an expensive but fun thing to do. Like visiting the Eiffel Tower in Paris, Colosseum in Rome and Statue of Liberty in NYC, seeing Hong Kong from atop Victoria Peak was necessary just to say you had done it.

title: Part of Victoria Peak tourist trappings...
text: For lunch at 12:30pm on a Thursday, the restaurant was basically empty so getting a table on the window with a nice view was not a problem. However, flagging down a server was a different issue. The bill for our two glasses of wine and an order of Steamed Mussels came to $50+ USD and of course included a fixed 10% Service Charge. This was our first experience at a Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. restaurant and will probably be our last. It turned out to just be a disappointing part of the Victoria Peak tourist trappings.

title: Chinese American seeking Chinese food in Tirana...
text: While leisurely taking in some of the sights of Tirana, we came upon the Chinese Garden Restaurant. After looking over the menu, we decided to return for dinner. Despite the fact that we were the only customers at 8pm on a Thursday night, the waiter was still more than attentive but also genuinely friendly and professional. It was definitely not surprising that after indulging in wines and enjoying excellent entrees, the bill was a reasonable $53 USD before gratuity. The restaurant was on the second floor of the garden, clean, nicely decorated and spacious. As a Chinese American seeking Chinese food in Tirana, I was more than satisfied with our restaurant choice and would return in a heartbeat.

title: More than a cut above...
text: As Hilton Diamond, we choose Hilton family properties frequently and found the Hilton Garden Inn Tirana definitely more than a cut above the typical HGI. Our suite was well-appointed, clean and comfortable, and the hotel in general was upscale, spacious and inviting. To a person, the staff were always willing to please, professional and seemed quite happy. Located close to Tirana's primary attractions, the hotel most importantly (for us) felt completely secure and safe. The dining area had more of a restaurant feel to it, and the breakfasts were quite good. We tend to find the Hilton family properties outside of the USA to be much nicer than the normal cookie-cutter USA approach, and the Hilton Garden Inn Tirana was a perfect example...a top shelf property.

title: Bunkers abound in Albania...
text: Since bunkers abound in Albania, our visit to Tirana would not have been complete without experiencing at least one of these structures. Preserved and converted to a museum, Bunk'Art2 was conveniently located in Central Tirana. The go-at-your-own-pace self-guided tour took us less than an hour at a leisurely pace. The exhibits covered all aspects of life under Communism and were most educational.

title: A feast...
text: The docent at the Public Palace recommended we have dinner at Ristorante Bolognese, and a disappointment it was not. We would probably not have found this relatively small, quiet restaurant on our own, as there were so many dining options in San Marino, and restaurant hawkers, from whom we normally stay away. were everywhere. After indulging in some nice wine, our meal consisted of fresh salads, grilled branzino, scallops, tortellini and spaghetti dishes. It was indeed a feast, and although a bit pricey at 62.80 euro, it was a memorable experience.
placeLocation: City of San Marino, San Marino

title: Very accommodating...
text: Arriving in San Marino on a Saturday night and then hoping to have a nice dinner at 9pm without a reservation was a challenge. On recommendation of my hotel, Il Ristorante Beccafico was very accommodating. They were quite full and very busy, but the service was excellent, food very good and prices more than reasonable. I definitely appreciated having a nice glass of wine, dinner and quickly being back at my hotel and would return for a more leisurely evening...without the presence of the Pirelli car rally contingents.
placeLocation: City of San Marino, San Marino

title: Convenient to train station but expensive...
text: Ristorante Capitale della Cina was convenient to the train station but expensive for chinese cuisine. The food was definitely a step above that which was seemingly available near the station and actually quite tasty. Since I was there for lunch at Noon, there were few other patrons, and the wait staff seemed involved with other matters. For Chicken Fried Rice, a beverage and the mandatory cover charge per table, the $14 USD was pretty steep. Nice, clean surroundings and decor, as well as clean restrooms, were a plus. However, sitting in the area immediately adjacent to the entry door was not good.

title: Beautiful courtyard a joy to behold...
text: We spent part of our last morning in Phnom Penh at the National Museum of Cambodia. Unless you are really into artifacts, spending a few hours at most would be sufficient to see some wonderful Khmer ceramics and particularly sculptures and to experience the highlights of this huge collection. The beautiful courtyard of the museum was an absolute joy to behold.

title: Set price for English-speaking tour guide...
text: As Royal Palaces go, Cambodia's was actually quite interesting. Unfortunately, access to most of the buildings was restricted. It is smaller in size compared to other royal complexes such as Thailand's, so walking around was actually easier. Upon paying the entrance fee, there were English-speaking tour guides available for a set price. This was pleasant and thus eliminated any haggling or feelings of price creep for Westerners. As expected, the grounds were immaculate and buildings well maintained. The Silver Pagoda was interesting but did not quite live up to all the hype. It was naturally the most crowded attraction of the Royal Palace complex. We were actually quite impressed by the beautiful murals adorning the interior walls of the pagoda complex. The Royal Palace of Cambodia compound was definitely one of the limited highlights of Phnom Penh.

title: Much more than just an entertaining show...
text: Continued preservation of the performing arts in Cambodia is embodied in Experience Cambodian Living Arts. It is said that some 90% of Cambodia's artists did not survive the regime of the Khmer Rouge. The work of Experience Cambodian Living Arts serves to nurture the country's rich heritage of traditional dances. As such, the performance of "Earth and Sky" was much more than just an entertaining show. Being able to attend was a great way to provide a very small contribution in support of the arts scene of Cambodia and enjoy a great evening out at the same time.
place: Experience Cambodian Living Arts, Dance Show

title: Perfect outing to get away from Phnom Penh madness...
text:
A later pick-up at our hotel was negotiated with the tour operator, so that we could enjoy our breakfast. As it turned out, we had the entire boat to ourselves which was wonderful, and our English-speaking guide was both entertaining and informative. They normally provide unlimited beer and soft drinks, but since we do not drink beer, they gladly offered to stop and buy wine for us. That was a very nice gesture, but we were good and drank water the entire day...so much healthier for us. Fresh fruits were served both going up river and down. Taking in the scenes along the banks of the Tonle Sap River was really fun and educational. Although the first stop at Koh Chen Island and the village of silversmiths was not without additional voluntary monetary outlay, the silver handicrafts were astoundingly beautiful and will serve as special holiday gifts in December.

After a brief lunch stop to enjoy a sampling of local cuisine, we were off to experience the former Cambodian royal capital city of Oudong, as well as the largest Buddhist center in the country. We took our time climbing up to see the burial sites of former kings, but the views from atop were spectacular and worth the effort. And the return boat ride was especially nice after the long day to just hang out, hydrate and relax. It was the perfect outing to get away from the madness which is Phnom Penh.
place: Oudong and Koh Chen Island - Full Day Cruise & Tour with English speaking guide

title: Patronized by professionals and embassy staff...
text: The Bellevue Serviced Apartments were perfect for our four-night visit to Cambodia's capitol city. Removed from the primary tourist areas but close enough to easily and quickly become immersed in the Phnom Penh scene when desired, our spacious two-bedroom apartment with full kitchen was ideal. Although we dined out several times during our stay, we also took full advantage of our cooking facilities for snacks, beverages, lunches and dinners. Our complimentary hot breakfasts were tasty, varied daily and were delivered directly to our apartment at times of our choosing. Entry to the property from the main road was secured by gates and guards, so safety was never a concern. Since we learned that the apartment complex was patronized by professionals and embassy staff who were either visiting or employed at the numerous foreign missions, it was not surprising that the property appeared prominently on all our maps and that our shared-services drivers knew exactly where to go. Our primary staff contact was with their Front Desk personnel, who were quite friendly and helpful. There was a small store on property which carried a limited selection of food items and sundries but most importantly carried some nice wines. The hotel pool was definitely a plus. Not only was it always clean but mostly devoid of other people...probably because they were working during the day. Should we ever choose to return to Phnom Penh, the Bellevue Serviced Apartments would be our "go to" choice.

title: Pleasant dining option...
text: In the Siem Reap tourist area of Pub Street, there are an infinite number of fast food establishments and street vendor carts of varying shapes and sizes from which to choose. However, we found The Central Cafe to be a refreshing, pleasant dining option for a more traditional meal. Our dinner items included Stir-fried Morning Glory, Grilled Squid, Grilled Marinated Pork, Beef Skewer, Mixed Green Salads, Deep-fried Spring Rolls and a Seafood Vermicelli Salad. We were all pleased with our menu selections and shared some tasting portions. The options for beverages were as extensive as the food menu. Sitting inside the restaurant and being able to people watch while avoiding the crowd crush was a good choice.

title: Nothing exceptional but palatable...
text: Rom Chang Angkor Restaurant was the choice of our tour guide. We were happy just to be able to sit down, take a break from seeing temples and enjoy cool beverages. We ordered Vegetable Spring Rolls for appetizers, and Stir-fried Morning Glory in oyster sauce, Fried Prawn with Black Mushrooms, Stir-fried Fish with Black Mushrooms and Fried Noodles as entrees. The food was nothing exceptional but palatable. Asian cuisine at inflated Western prices was not what we would have expected in Cambodia. Service was quite disorganized and sporadic at best.

title: Part of tour-guide routing but for a reason...
text: After visiting five Angkor temples on what was probably a typical itinerary, we thankfully stopped for lunch. The Khmer Village Restaurant was our destination. Already clearly packed with tourists, we were directed to an enclosed dining area with AC. This restaurant was obviously part of a tour-guide routing system. However, as we discovered, it was for a reason. The service was attentive, food very good and prices a bit high for Cambodia but reasonable. Our orders of Vegetable Spring Rolls, Mango Salads, Fried Egg, Stir-fried Pork, Chicken Currry and steamed rice were quite tasty. Foreign travelers being foreign travelers, it is better for local tour guides to be able to rely upon quality consistency. In our opinion, Khmer Village Restaurant did a excellent job.

title: Never showed with pre-ordered dinner...
text: We had a confirmed pre-order for delivery between 7:30 and 8pm. We had placed the order several weeks ahead of time to ensure they would be open, so we could set the date for a virtual birthday dinner party. We, of course, are obeying the local stay-at-home dictate. At 7:30pm, we confirmed that the order was in process but had not yet been sent out. By 8pm, when we connected with the other parties on the virtual dinner call who had received their delivered meals, ours still showed in process! At 8:10pm, we canceled the order from La Tratto Santa Lucia and quickly put together a frozen pizza at home. Luckily, we had our own bottle of wine and did not have to rely upon La Tratto. But the damage was done and an anticipated fun evening had been totally spoiled. So when it comes time to again start patronizing local restaurants, we will be sure to SKIP La Tratto Santa Lucia. There will be more than a few responsible establishments who will want business again.

title: An overview of primary temples and ancient buildings...
text:
While many visitors to Cambodia will not surprisingly immediately equate the country to the Angkor Wat temple and others may conjure up images of the Ta Prohm temple used in filming Tomb Raider starring Angelina Jolie, in actuality, this UNESCO World Heritage site encompasses over 400 square kilometers with hundreds of temples, ancient structures and monuments. We only visited some 25 sites but literally took hundreds of photos. However, rather than post reviews for each of the attractions we visited, we have chosen to simply provide an overview of primary temples and ancient buildings. There are more than a sufficient number of reviews and photos for specific Angkor attractions already here on Trip Advisor.

We purchased an Angkor World Heritage Pass for $62USD which was valid for use any three days within ten days from date of purchase. They take your picture which is imprinted on the pass, so it is non-transferable...and also serves as a great souvenir. Unless you are a temple junkie, three days is more than ample time to experience all of the Park's highlights. We made the good decision to retain a reputable tour guide, who also provided all transportation from and back to our hotel. Not to be missed of course are the Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm temples, as well as Angkor Thom City and its Bayon, Baphoun and Phimeanakas temples and remnants of the Royal Palace. Although a bit farther out from the primary cluster of Angkor temples, Banteay Srey was beautiful and well worth the 30-minute ride. There are a myriad of smaller, but no less impressive, temples to visit. Some of the ones which we enjoyed most were Bateay Samre, Ta Som, Pre Rup, Preah Khan, Neak Pean and Mebon temples. At varying points during our second and third days, there really was complete saturation and a return to our hotel pool for snacks, beverages and some relaxation was necessary. We also opted not to tour for three days in a row and instead were able to take a day off to do other Siem Reap exploration. However, make no mistake, as much as you choose to experience of Angkor Archaeological Park, it is well worth the time and effort. In this review, multiple photos of the temples are included for your viewing. Enjoy!

title: Chinese dining in a luxurious setting...
text: We found ourselves overnight during the Chinese New Year weekend in Ho Chi Minh City and in search of a decent restaurant for dinner. Yeebo Seafood & Hot Pot Restaurant looked quite inviting from street level and ended up being an excellent random choice. Finding out that they also served a Max Reserva Chilean white wine was definitely a plus. Our family-style dishes consisted of Chinese Mushrooms with Vegetables, a Steamed Chicken, Fried Flat Rice Noodles with Beef and steamed rice. This was fine Chinese dining in a luxurious setting, impeccable service and amazingly delicious food.

title: Server spoke English...
text: An overnight in HCM to change planes from Cambodia to USA found us looking for food midday on Monday of the Chinese New Year holiday. It was not the best time to find anything open for lunch. However, we happened upon Com Tam Cali and were pleasantly surprised...not that we had a lot of choices. There was only one other table in use and the staff were in the middle of a shift change. Our server spoke English which was a plus but was about to end her shift. She graciously helped us decipher their menu, suggested food items and stayed to take our orders before clocking out. Our rice noodles, broken rice and chicken rice dishes were quite tasty and only lacking a nice glass of white wine. The restaurant was well-maintained and prices very reasonable. The cost was less than five dollars each which included six bottles of water to go. Happy to have found this place.

title: Be prepared for cats underfoot while dining...
text: Quite touristy but still a decent Cambodian dining experience. We had heard about Titanic Restaurant from a friend, as well as one of our tour guides. Due to its incredible location alongside and overlooking the river, the view is difficult to replicate or beat. However, the nice visuals were not going to fill our bellies. Thankfully, the food was actually quite good...albeit a bit pricey. Several glasses of wine, Lemongrass Soup with Beef, Traditional Steamed Fish in Lime Juice, and a special order of Fish Amok (Kor Ku Soup with fish) made for a tasty dinner. If we had been more adventurous and not needed the foreigner touch, then there were a multitude of other dining options in the area. Be prepared to have cats of all shapes and sizes being underfoot while you are dining. The wait staff were more interested in chatting with one another than providing good service.

title: A favorite of locals and entrance was easy to miss...
text: The dining experience was luckily very nice but would have been substantially different if the restaurant known as Moon River had firstly not been suggested by our hotel, and secondly, if we had not gone with a local friend. Our hotel suggested and made advance reservations, so when we arrived to a very large, chaotic and packed Song Trang, we were pleased when shown to a more secluded, quiet table overlooking the river. Since little to no English was spoken by the staff, being there with our Vietnamese friend was a must. The restaurant is supposedly a favorite of locals and frequently hosts large groups and family celebrations. Since our visit was on a Friday night at the start of the Lunar New Year weekend, the restaurant had a wonderfully festive, electric atmosphere. Although we had received specific directions from our hotel to the restaurant, the entrance was easy to miss. We actually walked by several times. The meal we ordered was the equivalent of a family-style banquet and was excellent. With drinks and desserts, the total cost for the four of us was a whopping $32 USD! And the servers, even though harried, were extremely friendly, professional and responsive. Tipping was supposedly not expected but clearly appreciated. Now comparing all of the above dining experience to most anywhere in the USA, is there something wrong with the picture?

title: Interest probably correlates with one's age...
text: Although the Futurium was an intriguing Berlin attraction and worth the short wait in line due to free admission, we were not particularly impressed overall. Admittedly, in its entirety, the concept is creative and novel. We suspect that one's level of interest probably correlates with one's age. Young people, and particularly families with children, would find the Futurium more engaging.

title: Extremely worthwhile, sobering exhibition...
text: As tourists, we have been fortunate to have visited Berlin numerous times and have taken in the many landmarks and famous sights. However, for some unknown reason, the Topography of Terror Museum had never previously come up as an attraction. Much to our surprise, it was an extremely worthwhile, sobering exhibition. The museum was quite crowded (in part because there is no admission fee and we were there on a weekend), but the ability to easily navigate from exhibit to exhibit allowed for excellent viewing. We found it advantageous to leisurely appreciate the photos and explanations and to be able to spend as much time as we desired. This museum is definitely a "must see" when in Berlin.

title: A perfect casual and enjoyable dining experience...
text: For dinner, our hotel only served bar snacks and pizzas. We were surprised to find that on a Monday at 7pm there were limited decent options available. Cafe Bleibtreu was an unexpected find with a local flair. A few glasses of Riesling, bowls of lentil soup, some grilled mushrooms and Jagerschnitzels provided a perfect casual and enjoyable dining experience. As a plus, the waitress was a total hoot!

title: Superlative adjectives fail...
text: The Vasa Museum is definitely a must-see Stockholm attraction. The Vasa, a 17th Century Swedish warship, was salvaged in 1961 after 333 years under water. Although partially reconstructed, it is 98 percent original and truly magnificent. In describing the Vasa, superlative adjectives fail.

title: Excellent food but rude waiters...
text: We entered the half-filled restaurant on a Thursday night without a reservation. Although we were seated immediately by one of the four waiters standing around at the front counter, the waiter acted like he had no time for us. We even had to later flag another waiter down to ask for a menu. We enjoyed our chardonnays, mixed salad, Caprese with avocado, Rigatoni Salsiccia and Linguine Mare dishes. Mia Italian Kitchen Dairy served excellent food but rude waiters did not impress. Perhaps this restaurant needs to rest not only on its food output but also work on good customer service. At exceptional establishments, the two go hand in hand.

title: Owned by Chinese and no longer a Hilton...
text: When we stayed here, it was the Hilton Edinburgh Grosvenor. As Hilton Diamond members, we could not help but notice that the property was badly in need of not just a facelift but also substantial interior repairs and attention to customer services. So we decided to inquire of various staff as to why. We learned that the property had recently been purchased by Chinese who were making numerous changes and not putting money into the property. There were no longer bell persons, but someone from the front desk needed to also serve as bellhops. The restaurant was separate from hotel operations, so there was literally no communication between departments. The Chinese intended to eliminate the typical hot buffet found in Scotland and replace it with a cold continental breakfast. Housekeeping had apparently been contracted out. Our suite, although upgraded, was very sparsely furnished and not particularly clean. The saving grace for the hotel was that it was located within a reasonable walking distance from the main tourist attractions. However, since we were not impressed with this hotel during our stay, we would definitely not recommend it now that it is owned by the Chinese and no longer a Hilton property.

title: Had hoped to witness rude exchanges like on the news...
text: Although is was worth the visit and a regimented stop in the visitor's gallery, we had hoped to witness rude exchanges like on the news, but the government representative was a no show! We sat through some minutes of very boring discussions and left.

title: A very expensive view...
text: The only way to reach the viewing platforms on Bob's Peak above Queenstown was to take the Skyline Gondola. If you have been on an aerial tramway before, then the ride would be nothing new, except that the vertical climb was steeper than most. It was actually a nice experience and the vistas were impressive. However, even given the sights of Queenstown, the beauty of Lake Wakatipu and the expanse of The Remarkables Mountain Range, at $39 each, it was a very expensive view. So go up on a nice day and take lots of pictures to make it pay off.
place: Queenstown Skyline Gondola Including Buffet Lunch or Dinner

title: A Five-Star resort and more...
text: Having spent almost a month touring New Zealand and loving every moment, we were pleased to have selected the Hilton Queenstown Resort & Spa for our final stop before returning home. It was definitely a Five-Star resort and more. We were a bit apprehensive that the Hilton might be located too far from Queenstown proper, but we knew we would have a rental car and decided not to worry. As it turned out, we would not need the car except for day tours outside of the immediate area. The resort had a water taxi service which transported guests to and from downtown Queenstown, and instead of $15 roundtrip, we just presented our room key and the fare was reduced to $5 each way. So the more secluded location allowed us to enjoy the sights and sounds of Queenstown and then leave the tourist mess behind and return to the tranquility of the resort. Our accommodations left nothing wanting. The fireplace, private balcony, elevated sleeping room and fantastic views of Lake Wakatipu and the mountains were perfect for kicking back over a nice glass of wine and snacks. We actually never chose to leave the serenity of the Hilton to go to town for dinners the entire week. There were three restaurants on property, and the food at each was very good to excellent. The breakfast buffet was quite hearty with something for almost everyone's taste. A table by the windows fronting on the lake was preferable. Without exception, the staff were fantastic...friendly, helpful, entertaining and professional. We were even lucky enough to meet some of the management team. We would someday love to return and do highly recommend it.

title: A unique window into the past...
text:
Our viewing of the Arrowtown Chinese Settlement was truly a unique window into the past. To be able to leisurely walk amongst some of the preserved and partially restored mid-1800 "gold rush" era dwellings of the Chinese miners was eye opening.
The preserved Chinese settlement was located in an area below and outside of the original town and along Bush Creek. The stark contrast, between the pristine European Arrowtown Village and where the Chinese miners were forced to live, was both telling and defining of the times. Remains of the modest stone cottages of the settlement were a testament to the hardy nature and perhaps intrinsic values and character of the Chinese gold miners. We were able to actually enter some huts to imagine and experience how harsh the living conditions might have been.

title: Quaint...
text: A visit to Arrowtown Village was prompted by our interest in seeing what had been a real gold mining town, the Arrowtown Chinese Settlement and several ghost towns in the surrounding hills. We actually enjoyed spending our several hours exploring a few of the many shops and taking pictures of the more quaint structures. However, there are many similar venues around the world, so Arrowtown Village was not particularly unique. Perhaps its mining history could set it apart, but we simply recalled some of the towns in Nevada and California in the USA. The restored and preserved Chinese Settlement, though, definitely puts this New Zealand village on the map.

title: Exceptional dining experience...
text: For our final dinner in New Zealand after touring the country for almost a month, we reserved a window table at the Wakatipu Grill with the wonderful views of the lake and surrounds. Our choices of their Provenance Roasted Lamb Rack and the 300g Aged Wakanui Rib-eye were delicious beyond belief...cooked to perfection and beautifully presented. The Chocolate Fondant with roasted white chocolate and macadamia ice cream, as well as the Braeburn Apple dessert, were fitting exclamation points to an exceptional dining experience.

title: Casual dining option at the Hilton...
text: Of the three primary eateries at the Hilton, Stacks Pub was by far the casual dining option. As the name would imply, this restaurant had more of a bar atmosphere and filled up with a younger, noisier clientele. Luckily, we chose to dine earlier than usual one evening and enjoyed several complimentary drinks with our Mixed Green Salad and Stacks Favourite Pizza before the crowd arrived. The chicken, red onion, mushroom and crumbled feta cheese pizza was actually quite good. It was nice, however, to get back to the serenity of our suite and relax over several glasses of wine.

title: Enjoyable experience and excellent Chinese food...
text: Since we were staying at the Hilton, we decided to avoid the trip into town and try the Me & Mee Chinese Restaurant which was perfectly convenient. We had an enjoyable experience and excellent Chinese food, so we even returned later in our stay for a second time. Over the course of our two dinners, we were able to try their Prawn Wonton Soup with Vegetables, Steamed Whole Fish, Sauteed Lamb with Leeks, Chicken and Sweet Corn Soup, Fried Rice with Vegetables and Egg, Stir-fried Beef with Ginger and Spring Onions, and the Stir-fried Chicken in a Black Bean Sauce. All of the dishes were nicely presented and very savory. Although the atmosphere was nothing special, the restaurant was clean, bright and comfortable.

title: Be adventurous and explore some ghost towns...
text: We had planned an excursion from Queenstown to historic Arrowtown but decided to do some additional exploring in the general area. We had read about Bendigo, a gold-mining town occupied until the early 1900's, as well as several settlements deserted since the 1880's in the hills above. Although we did not expect to find anything close to a Hollywood set, we were clearly not sure what we would find. But we chose to be adventurous and explore some of these "ghost towns" from over a century ago. There was not much left of Bendigo, but Welshtown higher up the hill was replete with partial buildings and signs of prior occupancy. It was actually quite exciting to be able to step back over 100 years in time. Although we only had a Mazda rental car, the dry conditions allowed us to navigate the roads quite nicely. We would suggest, however, having an off-road vehicle to access these areas during inclement conditions. There were some striking views from where both Bendigo and Welshtown previously existed.

title: Do not visit primarily for Kiwis...
text: Although their name would suggest otherwise, do not visit the Kiwi Birdlife Park primarily to view the kiwis. You could be disappointed. We were not because the possibility of viewing kiwis, while certainly important, was not the only motivating factor for our visit. The fact that the park was home to not only kiwis but numerous endangered native bird species was of particular interest. We expected to see a rare black stilt, but it had unfortunately died prior to our visit. This attraction is entirely funded by admission fees and is heavily involved in rehabilitation, as well as breeding of national birds. We would have loved a photo of the kiwis while they were foraging for food, but the use of cameras was understandably strictly prohibited. The cost of admission, while not inexpensive, was worth contributing to the conservation efforts being undertaken by the Kiwi Birdlife Park. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit and considered a return entry which was included in our admission fee but unfortunately neither had the time nor the opportunity during our short five-night stay in Queenstown.

title: Still beautiful on a cloudy day...
