text: Even though Lake Pukaki was still beautiful on a cloudy day, we would have really liked to have had a view of the mountains as well. The exceptional blue waters of the lake were stunningly visible and no less blue.

title: Influences of nature on the human psyche...
text: Driving to Queenstown from the destruction wrought by nature in Christchurch, we stopped to admire the tranquil and beautiful vistas at Lake Tekapo. Although clearly a juxtaposition, it was a refreshing reminder of the incredible positive influences of nature on the human psyche.

title: Last-minute Thanksgiving menu option much appreciated...
text:
The location of Chateau on the Park - Christchurch, a DoubleTree by Hilton property was undeniably excellent given its proximity to the huge green open space of Hagley Park and the beautiful Botanic Gardens. We enjoyed being within a leisurely walking distance of attractions in Central Christchurch, such as the Canterbury Museum and Canterbury National Earthquake Memorial. We enjoyed a nice accommodation with a partial view of the Gazebo Gardens, and the hotel staff throughout were personable and helpful. They were no doubt taking their cue from David Wain, Hotel Manager...a nice guy. However, for us, the Certificate of Excellence should go to the Food & Beverage team.

Our complimentary full breakfast, especially the made-to-order omelette, was perfect. One morning we asked to see the full dinner menu, mainly curious what we might order for dinner that evening (which happened to be our Thanksgiving) and noticed they did not have any turkey on the menu. When we inquired of our server and explained the reason, she went to check with the Head Chef. Several minutes later, she returned to advise that they would be happy to prepare a dish from their special "Christmas" menu for our dinner. Upon our return from a full-day excursion to Akaroa and arrival for our dinner reservation, we were totally surprised to find that the Garden Court Brasserie restaurant was promoting availability of a full roast turkey dinner! Apparently, as a result of our inquiry at breakfast, they had arranged for the special dinner offering. Needless-to-say, the last-minute Thanksgiving menu option was not only very much appreciated but also the meal was excellent. Further, when we asked if there were any cranberries, sauce or jelly for the turkey, after some minutes of apparent search and destroy, our server returned with apologies from the chef. And then only after several more minutes, the chef himself returned with cranberry sauce. He explained that he knew they had some but that it had taken time for him to find it...amazing service! The following morning, the Head Chef thanked us because they had totally sold out the special dinner offering the previous evening. The thanks was really from us to all of them! For three days, we not only took every breakfast in the hotel but also all our dinners in either the restaurant or Den Bar Lounge. In our opinion, there was no need to explore other venues with the proven track record within the hotel. Also, in lieu of an Executive Lounge (which most DoubleTree-branded properties do not have anyway), the daily drink vouchers were nice. Our sincere thanks to Chris, Akiko, the Head Chef, the Night Chef and Donna!
place: Chateau on the Park - Christchurch, a DoubleTree by Hilton

title: Stop and smell the roses...
text: We walked through the Christchurch Botanic Gardens at every opportunity going to and from our hotel and the attractions of the city. Photo ops within the gardens abound, but since we are particularly fond of roses, the Rose Garden was a definite draw. Although we did not take the time to do so in a single excursion, a complete tour of the gardens could probably take several hours. We instead preferred to frequently just stop and smell the roses when passing through.

title: Actually very depressing...
text: The reminders of death and destruction from the earthquake were just too vivid. Although there was evidence of substantial rebuilding efforts and a city literally digging out, the visual realities of Christchurch Cathedral, Cathedral of the Blessed Sacrament, Cathedral Square and surrounds was actually quite depressing. This "attraction" should really be rated Terrible or not at all.

title: Sadly powerful...
text: The Canterbury Earthquake National Memorial was at the top of our list of Christchurch points of interest. While viewing the memorial and absorbing its sadly powerful message, we could not help but be moved by a number of people (mostly individual men) who were seated on the benches and quietly self-absorbed. We could only imagine who they may have lost. The urge to take photos of the memorial was superseded by the importance of not invading the aura of this special place. It shall be vividly engraved in our memories. God Bless all those who perished, as well as those who suffered a loss.

title: Well worth the voluntary donation for admission...
text: If for nothing more than the Bird Hall exhibits, our visit to the Canterbury Museum was well worth the voluntary donation for admission. Having toured a multitude of museums worldwide, we have found that there tends to always be a singular exhibit or emphasis which stands out...aside from the spotlight on a unique local or national culture. Thus, the Maori exhibits were of course of interest. The "Christchurch Street" exhibit was a lot of fun. However, the amazing and realistic bird displays were far and above the singular most impressive gallery.

title: Not just the formal museum but the town...
text: Approaching Akaroa through the outlying French farmlands, we started to get a sense of the original French settlers in 1840. The Akaroa Museum exhibited much of the town's historic heritage. The museum housed the town's old courthouse, as well as the Langlois-Eteveneaux House, believed to have originated in France and was then assembled in Akaroa in 1841...impressive. A stroll through the town provided even more examples of historical importance in some of the preserved buildings. The Coronation Library and numerous homes along the streets of Akaroa served as testement. This excursion was well worth the drive from Christchurch.

title: Well-maintained memorial and manicured grounds...
text: As war memorials go, the Banks Peninsula War Memorial and Grounds in the small town of Akaroa was well-maintained with manicured grounds surrounding. It was surprisingly serene, even though located on the main street. Its prominent location in the center of Akaroa exemplified the importance which New Zealanders impart to their fallen brethren. We took a moment to reflect upon the immense impact of conflicts throughout the world.
place: Banks Peninsula War Memorial and Grounds

title: A small lighthouse...
text: It was a short climb up the hill to reach Akaroa Lighthouse. The fact that it was originally built in the late 1870's and relocated to its present site in 1980 speaks more to its historical importance than anything else. Although there are nice views of Akaroa Harbour and the town of Akaroa, it was basically just a small lighthouse.

title: Kaikoura "very good"..."Why Not Cafe" "average"...
text: This review is primarily for Kaikoura and surrounds, but we also lunched at the Why Not Cafe. Since we could not find a way on Trip Advisor to just review Kaikoura and the beautiful surrounding coastline, we have combined reviews here. First, we decided to drive from Nelson to Christchurch using Highway 1 along the coast. Although we were aware of possible delays due to road repairs from the 2016 earthquake, we decided to take the purported more scenic route. We were definitely not disappointed. The views of the Pacific Ocean, coastline and wildlife were wonderful. Kaikoura was the mid-way point to Christchurch and a perfectly great place to leisurely stroll along the water and through the town. When stopped at one of the road construction checkpoints, we were able to chat with the "flagger" and inquire of restaurants in Kaikoura. As a local, her recommendation for a reasonable and basic lunch menu was the Why Not Cafe. We took her suggestion...and why not? The cafe was actually quite busy with a mix of tourists and obvious locals. It was truly just a cafe, so do not expect anything impressive. We opted for basic fish and chips, which was actually quite tasty. The prices were also extremely reasonable and the service acceptable for a small, busy cafe.

title: A Five-Star experience...
text: The Harbourside Lodge and our hosts Cathy and David provided a Five-Star experience during our visit to the Nelson City and Tasman Bay Region. Although we had a rental car, the hotel was conveniently located only a short walk along the Maitai River to the center of Nelson. Cathy was a wealth of information and happily suggested all number of local attractions and eateries. The responsibility for the complimentary breakfast fell to David, who not only served up a nice buffet but also entertaining conversation. Knowing that we would be spending three nights in Nelson midway through our month-long trip to New Zealand, we pre-booked their very nice one-bedroom apartment with marina view many months in advance. We were not to be disappointed. Both the main living/dining room/kitchen and the separate bedroom with King bed were well-appointed, airy and spacious. Each had its own balcony with views of the marina and distant mountains. The available on-property laundry facilities were definitely a plus when traveling for extended periods on the road...and they even provided the detergent. Cathy's familiarity with the local tour operators was also most helpful when considering who to use and for which tours. We could not have asked for a better overall experience.

title: World-class touring experience...
text: As you can see from our travels and reviews, we have been lucky enough to have visited a fair portion of the civilized world. However, as relates specifically to wine tasting and vineyard tours, we can only count South Africa, France, Chile, Argentina, Australia, New Zealand, Italy, Mexico, Spain, Germany, Portugal, Austria and even China, and of course the United States, amongst our wine tasting/vineyard tour experiences. We are admittedly not experts but very much savor a good vino. Among excursion options, Bay Tours Nelson advertised visits to varying numbers of wineries, depending upon one's tastes, time and desires. However, as anyone who has previously been on wine tours realizes, the selection and types of wines available for tasting at any given winery are solely up to the discretion of that particular winery...and not the tour operator. Owen provided a world-class touring experience with visits to Te Mania/Richmond Plains wineries, Brightwater Vineyards, Seifried Estate winery and Kahurangi Estate (for tasting and lunch). A stop at the Moutere Inn, the oldest pub in New Zealand still operating in its original building, was a great break from the wineries. Whenever possible, we stopped for some incredible vistas of Nelson and surrounds. We even had an opportunity to do some shopping for truly unique ornaments at the Eyebright Country Store Christmas shop. Simply put, there are not enough superlatives to describe Owen and Bay Tours Nelson. Without reservation, we would highly recommend any of their tours.
